issuetype.description: A small, distinct piece of work.
issuetype.name: Task

content.text: Script of the video: We have been brainwashed, into believing free speech means democracy and progress.
That if two sides can sit down, argue it out and explain their logic…
We’ll magically arrive at the right answer.
But that’s not how progress actually works.
What sounds logical, or “common sense” often collapses in reality.
Life is counterintuitive and full of paradoxes —
This is why most of the time you can’t argue or ‘reason’ your way into good decisions.
Scientists don’t do this.
Entrepreneurs don’t do this.
They don’t sit around debating philosophy all day —
Instead they run experiments.
They gather data.
They A/B test.
They iterate.
They run pilot studies.
They stress-test ideas against evidence.
Debate is only one tiny part of the decision-making stack — and usually not the most important.
Because debate can be rigged.
Rhetoric can mislead.
Statistics can be twisted.
A confident speaker can make a terrible idea sound brilliant.
And what feels intuitive can fail completely under real-world conditions.
Debate gives the illusion of freedom, because anyone can speak—but it also lets bad ideas win if they’re sold well enough.
This is the sleight of hand: the puppet master sets the choices, and the idea of free speech convinces the public they chose the option.
Noam Chomsky called this, ‘manufacturing consent’ and it’s exactly why politics prioritizes debate over the scientific method.
That’s why politicians shouldn’t just debate.
They should experiment.
They should test policies, gather data, run trials, measure results.
Less performance…
more proof.
Because real freedom and real progress don’t come from who can argue better —
they come from
what survives reality.

resolution.description: Work has been completed on this work item.
resolution.name: Done

issuetype.description: A small, distinct piece of work.
issuetype.name: Task

content.text: Script of the video:

If a hundred monkeys threw a hundred darts at a dart board and one hit the bullseye, we'd all agree that was just luck. But when the same randomness happens in life, we forget that we start assuming the monkey must be a genius dar player. That's what Nasim Taleb called, being fooled by randomness. We're wired to see patterns and chaos, to build stories after the fact.

So success feels like skill instead of chance. If a hundred people start a business, some will succeed purely because of probability. Yet we convince ourselves that the millionaire must have some rare intellect or genius. The truth is, if enough people take enough swings, someone's bound to hit a home run.

Now, of course, skill and intelligence matter, I am grossly oversimplifying here, but we tend to massively overestimate the role of intelligence and underestimate luck, timing, and circumstance. That's part of why over half the world's richest billionaires are in tech. Yes, gates and Jobs were brilliant, but it also helped that their careers overlapped with the IT revolution.

As Jeff Bezos once admitted, he quit studying physics at Princeton. After watching a classmate solve in minutes what took him days, tomorrow's billionaires will emerge where the next revolution happens, of course, in biotech clean energy and nanotech. So maybe millionaires aren't the smartest people in the room.

Maybe they're just the ones who took the swing and got lucky when the timing was right. What does set entrepreneurs apart is the pressure they face and the risks they take. So maybe we shouldn't begrudge lady look so much after all.

issuetype.name: Task

content.text: Script of the video :  Society shouldn't treat people equally because. To do so is confusing, sameness with fairness. Now, to illustrate this, Dawkin asks us to imagine a mother with two children, one child who has a headache, the other who has cancer, but she only has two painkillers with her. Treating them equally would mean giving each child one painkiller, but treating them as equals would mean giving both painkillers to the child With cancer.

Justice is about everyone matching the same, not everyone getting the same, and this is why societies that treat people equally or with equality. Create injustice in the name of justice. That's essentially the crux of his argument.

Society shouldn't treat people equally because to do so is confusing sameness with fairness. Now, to illustrate why Dawkin believes this, he asks us to imagine a mother who has two children, one child who has a headache, and the other who has cancer, but the mother only has two painkillers with her.

Treating them equally would mean giving each child one painkiller, but treating the children as equal would mean giving both painkillers to the child with the cancer justice still can argues is about everyone mattering the same, not everyone getting the same. And why equality can create injustice in the name of justice, and hence why it should be guard against.

resolution.description: Work has been completed on this work item.
resolution.name: Done

fields.summary: Why you shouldn't treat people equally - Video

content.text: Shared 2 versions with shaun for review:
Version 1
– I’ve kept this one crisp and more text-driven so the overall flow stays tight and uninterrupted. The focus here is on clarity and pacing rather than visual storytelling.
Why you shouldn’t treat people equally Version 1 (Crisp)
Version 2

– In this version, I’ve tried to build a continuous visual story using AI-generated visuals that evolve with the voiceover. I’ve intentionally avoided adding sound effects so that nothing distracts from the narration or breaks the immersion of the story.
Why you shouldn’t treat people equally Version 2 (Story Form)
Shared 2 revised versions with Shaun with updated voice overs:
Why you shouldn’t treat people equally V3
Why you shouldn’t treat people equally V4
Final Version shared with Shaun with incorporated feedback:
Why you shouldn’t treat people equally V4 Updated 2

issuetype.description: A small, distinct piece of work.
issuetype.name: Task

content.text: Since 2023, over 100 AI start-ups— have already become unicorns—hit billion-dollar valuations.
We’re seeing the rise of a whole new breed of entrepreneur—
Business used to mean, dedicating your life to one thing for twenty years—but it’s now about speed and leverage.
You will have students that instead of travelling, start companies in their gap years —
And build billion-dollar businesses in their parents’ basements, before their friends have even graduated.

When you can become a billionaire in a matter of years, you just don’t need the same kind of grit and perseverance entrepreneurs once had—and, that opens the door for a whole new type of entrepreneur.
Tomorrow’s entrepreneurs will be those that are the most decisive and the most focused.
In this world, perfectionism is going to be the enemy of entrepreneurship.
